title: ASL 8.3 — Quick Updates & Check-Ins ⏱️
objectives: Deliver short ASL updates using time-first framing
Use FINISH, STILL, and NOT-YET for progress reports
Check in with a partner and confirm understanding with repeat-back

vocab.def: Y-handshape moving forward; shows ongoing status.
Palm out, tongue slightly out, chin tilt; task delayed.
Share quick info; open hand moves forward.
Gesture of quick status check, often with raised brows.

sections.heading: Warm-Up: Time + Status
sections.body: Practice pairing time markers with status: **TODAY PROJECT STILL.** / **HOMEWORK NOT-YET.** / **EMAIL SEND FINISH.**

sections.heading: Model: 3-Part Update

media.alt: Signer giving quick update with 3 sentences
media.caption: Each line = time + task + status

sections.body:
Keep updates concise:  
1. **MONDAY HOMEWORK NOT-YET.**  
2. **TUESDAY CLASS PROJECT STILL.**  
3. **WEDNESDAY EMAIL SEND FINISH.**

sections.heading: Partner Drill: Check-In
sections.body: A asks: **UPDATE PLEASE?** (brows up). B replies with 2 tasks (use STILL, NOT-YET, FINISH). A repeat-backs one line to confirm understanding.

sections.heading: Mini-Showcase
sections.body: Record **15–20s**: Give 3 updates (STILL, NOT-YET, FINISH), then confirm with a partner repeat-back. Caption which task is finished, ongoing, or delayed.
sections.teacherNote: Emphasize time-first and status markers for clarity.

items.q: Correct gloss for 'Homework not finished yet':
Write a 3-line gloss update with STILL, NOT-YET, and FINISH.

items.prompt: Which is hardest: pacing short updates, using NOT-YET NMM, or adding repeat-back?

reflectionPrompt: Upload your 15–20s update clip with 3 status markers (STILL, NOT-YET, FINISH). Caption the status of each task.
summary: You practiced giving short updates with time-first framing and clear status markers. You also confirmed comprehension with repeat-back in a quick check-in.
